author: Surbhi Kaul
title: Heavy Rain In Kochi Leads To Waterlogging, IMD Forecasts Week-Long Showers Amid Monsoon Mayhem In Kerala | Times Now
text: Kochi: Heavy showers lashed the city on Thursday (August 1), causing a brief waterlogging situation in several places. Many areas, including MG Road, Pallimukku, and Shenoy's Junction, were inundated by the rain. However, the rain subsided in the city during the late afternoon. In view of the brief rainfall yesterday, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) has not issued any alerts for Friday (August 2) as of yet. KS Dileep Kumar, president of Ernakulam Vikasna Samithi, an NGO, said that the rain subsided after almost an hour yesterday. He added that the brief rainfall helped in avoiding flooding in Kochi. However, many places in the city, especially MG Road, faced moderate waterlogging, according to a TOI report. The weather conditions today are predicted to include a cloudy sky with one or two spells of rain or thundershowers. The maximum temperature is expected to be 30 degrees Celsius, and the minimum temperature may likely be 25 degrees Celsius. In the last 24 hours, the recorded rainfall was 11mm, and the relative humidity fluctuated between 87 percent and 89 percent. Kochi Weekly Weather ForecastThe city is expected to witness a week-long rainfall with temperatures remaining constant throughout the week. From August 2 to August 7, the maximum temperature will be 30 degrees Celsius, and the minimum will be 25 degrees Celsius. On August 2, 3, 4, and 5, the weather condition in Kochi is expected to include a cloudy sky with one or two spells of rain or thundershowers. On August 6 and 7, Kochi is predicted to have a cloudy sky with the possibility of rain or thundershowers. Shelter Camps Set Up In Ernakulam DistrictThe incessant rainfall on Tuesday in Kerala affected many parts of the Ernakulam District. Since then, Ernakulam rural police have been on high alert for emergency response 24x7. Additionally, shelter camps were set up in the district to rescue people residing in low-lying areas. The district authorities opened around 18 camps where 470 people from 138 families had been given refuge. Kerala Battles Floods And Landslides, Many Dead, Rescue Operations OngoingIn a rain-induced landslide in Kerala's Wayanad, many people were injured and displaced. Reportedly, more than 250 people died in the landslide. Rescue operations are ongoing to rescue the missing people.
